etymology.description: 齒(齒) (chǐ, "tooth") simplified by removing the central 多(多) (duō, "many") component, leaving 歯 + 止(止) (zhǐ, "stop") -> simplified form 齿
etymology.interpretation: The simplification process of 齒(齒) (chǐ, "tooth") involved removing the central complexity of the character to streamline writing while retaining the essential imagery related to teeth.
etymology.simplification: The character 齒(齒) was simplified by removing the middle component 多(多), which was deemed unnecessary for understanding the character's meaning related to 'tooth.'

examples.chinese: 医生建议刷齿(齒)，勤漱口水(勤漱口水)。
examples.pinyin: Yīshēng jiànyì shuā chǐ, qín shù kǒushuǐ。
examples.english: The doctor recommends brushing teeth and rinsing the mouth frequently.

examples.chinese: 老虎的齿非常锋利(老虎的齒非常鋒利)。
examples.english: The tiger's teeth are exceptionally sharp.

examples.chinese: 考古学家发现古器上隐约可见的齿痕(考古學家發現古器上隱約可見的齒痕)，推测古代工具的制造工艺(推測古代工具的製造工藝)。
examples.pinyin: Kǎogǔ xuéjiā fāxiàn gǔqì shàng yǐnyuē kějiàn de chǐhén, tuīcè gǔdài gōngjù de zhìzào gōngyì。
examples.english: Archaeologists discovered faint tooth marks on ancient utensils, suggesting the craftsmanship of ancient tools.
